nodes.text: VGC is a versatile, ultra-fast GPU error-bounded lossy compression framework that addresses key limitations of existing GPU lossy compressors for HPC
VGC provides three compression algorithms (No-delta, Delta, Outlier) and supports 1D, 2D, and 3D processing to adapt to diverse HPC data features
VGC implements Dimension-aware Delta Encoding that preserves spatial locality while remaining GPU-friendly through fused row-wise (and depth-wise) deltas and register-only buffering

VGC Memory-efficient Compression uses a kernel-fission design: kernel one profiles per-block compressed sizes and global scan to get exact total size, then cudaMalloc of exact size, kernel two reuses offsets to write compressed blocks, enabling dynamic allocation without preallocating worst-case buffer
VGC Selective Decompression reads block metadata and applies an early-stopping prefix-sum to locate and decompress only region(s) of interest, supporting writing back to compressed array

VGC fuses compression stages (quantization, dimension-aware delta, fixed-length encoding, optional outlier preservation) into a highly optimized GPU kernel (single kernel for standard modes) to achieve ultra-fast throughput
VGC maintains error-bounded lossy quantization as the only lossy step, ensuring reconstructed data quality is controlled by the specified error bound
Dimension-aware algorithms improve compression ratios compared to 1D flattening; e.g., VGC-O 3D yields up to ~51% higher ratio than 1D on RTM Pressure1000
No-delta algorithm (VGC-N) is suited for random data like ML weights, Delta for sparse/locally smooth data, and Outlier for globally smooth datasets where preserving block-first values helps

Implementation optimizations (vectorized memory instructions, warp-coalesced accesses, register-only delta fusion) allow VGC kernels to approach GPU memory bandwidth and avoid shared-memory and branch-divergence penalties
Memory-efficient mode incurs overhead from an extra kernel and cudaMalloc but achieves substantial real-time GPU memory footprint reduction while maintaining ~70% of standard throughput

Selective Decompression activates few threads, early-stopping prefix-sum reduces synchronization cost, and throughput for selective ROI access reaches ~1.11 TB/s (single-precision) and ~2.08 TB/s (double-precision)
Evaluations on 13 real-world HPC datasets on an NVIDIA A100 show VGC average single-precision throughput ~322 GB/s (compression) and ~468 GB/s (decompression), and double-precision ~595/995 GB/s

Compared to state-of-the-art baselines, VGC achieves comparable or higher throughput and consistently better or comparable compression ratios (VGC-O higher than cuSZp2 on 12/13 datasets, up to 86% higher on JetIn), with similar reconstructed quality under same error bound

Two real-world use cases validate VGC versatility: (a) LLM KV-cache compression reduces GPU KV memory by ~46% while delivering ~211 GB/s compression and ~296 GB/s decompression with negligible application fidelity loss; (b) in-situ compression for a 256 GB turbulence field reduces transfer time up to 12.5x with pipeline overlap using GPUDirect RDMA
